Syllabus_Link:
Course Description
Develop the skills and strategies you need to become an integral part of one of America’s fastest growing service sectors. In this course students will come to understand the unique characteristics of nonprofit organizations while mastering the core knowledge necessary to become an effective leader in the nonprofit arena. Students will learn skills and develop strategies that will take organizations to new heights of prosperity and productivity. They will gain a full understanding the role of the executive director and the board of directors, public relation strategies, and fundraising for nonprofits to include developing a plan for grants and other fundraising efforts and how to find a position in this fascinating and rewarding field of work.
This is an activity and project based course. The learning is hands-on, and as such, you will be evaluated for the practical knowledge you demonstrate in completing assignments and projects.
2
Guilford College Five Academic Principles
This class encourages innovative student-centered learning by emphasizing class discussion,
requiring individual and group presentations, and by relating the content and principles to
students’ personal experiences. It provides a challenge to engage in critical and creative
thinking by requiring students to analyze real nonprofit organizations and by encouraging them
to develop and support their own lines of reasoning by decoding Requests for Proposals (RFP’s)
for fundraising. The class will address the importance of global or international program and
grant collaboration and diverse cultural perspectives of how funding for nonprofit organizations
is distributed. One of the predominant themes of the course is how granting agencies and
foundations promote their missions and how funding decisions reflect organizational values, as
well as how they relate to justice, and how sometimes those values and can change over time.
Ethics and social responsibility of nonprofit organizations are recurring themes, as well as
specific topics within the course. This class emphasizes practical applications because most of
the concepts are relevant to the everyday life of each of us, and students are required to make
these practical connections throughout the course.
Course Learning Outcomes/Objectives
Upon completion of this course, students should be able to:
1. Demonstrate an understanding of the key differences between the non-profit, for-profit and
public sectors, non-profit governance, operations, and fiscal aspects of non-profit organizations.
2. Articulate the different financial planning challenges facing non-profits, compared to the for profit 
sector.
3. Demonstrate an understanding of the fundamentals of various types of fundraising.
4. Demonstrate an understanding of the various types of fundraising campaigns and choose the
most appropriate one to implement.
5. Demonstrate an understanding of endowments and special funds.
6. Demonstrate understanding of handling/processing grants.
7. Demonstrate an understanding of fund accounting and bylaws.

Course  Syllabus



General  Studies 110						   Spring    2014
Quantitative  Literacy						                   


Instructor:  Mrs. Tresca Byrd                                                                      Class A: King B-26
                                                                                                M & W 8:30 AM-9:45 PM
Email: byrdmt@guilford.edu
Preferred: trescambyrd@embarqmail.com			    Class B: FRNK  329
	                                                                                       M & W 11:30AM-12:45 PM
Office: Duke Memorial B11-C                                              	
(or by appointment-3368178232)


Grading   (You will be provided a website to view your performance) 

This class is a credit/no credit class.  Therefore, a student does not receive a grade on the official college transcript, but rather earns or does not earn credit for the course.  In order to earn the two credits, a student must:

•	Pass the final exam/Quantitative Literacy Test 
•	Earn 80% of the possible points recorded for exercises and assignments 
•	Not miss more than four class sessions 


Work handed in should be clearly labeled.  For the mathematical assignments, the students should hand in their work by Exercise Set.  Be sure to include your work as well as your thoughts.  Also, the final answers should be circled or highlighted in some visible manner.  Work can be made up and resubmitted for grading.  Students should expect to hand in all work as scheduled.  While each student may work at his/her own pace, there will be a scheduled time for completed work to be passed in to ensure that students are moving forward.

Students are expected to initially attempt to work each problem on their own.  Getting stuck and figuring out how to get unstuck is part of the learning process we each go through.  Students may certainly seek help, but it is important that you do not confuse getting the correct answers with knowing and understanding the material.  In this course, it is strongly recommended that you focus on becoming more skilled and getting a better understanding of how to do the problems, rather than merely getting the correct answers.

Syllabus_Link:
Course Learning Outcomes/Objectives
Upon completion of this course, students should be able to:
1)	Provide an understanding of the history and development of grant making in both government and foundation settings.
2)	Provide an understanding of differences in grants by type, including conditions and the method of allocation.
3)	Convey knowledge of where and how to find information about available grants from public and private sources.
4)	Determine how to evaluate a potential grant opportunity in light of organization goals and objectives.
5)	Enhance your understanding of inter-organizational collaboration and intra-organizational team building around the grants enterprise.
6)	Convey technical knowledge and skills necessary to compile a grant budget according to standards.
7)	Provide knowledge of technical terms and concepts you will confront in the grant-seeking enterprise.
8)	Write effective grant program narrative descriptions.
9)	Organize quality applications in a timely fashion according to agency expectations.
10)	Understand key concepts associated with accepting and managing grant awards, including reporting and auditing requirements and program evaluation.
